title: Latitude’s death by a thousand cuts
text:
It failed both because of what it was, and what it wasn’t.

It was a private equity-backed float. The market’s inherent suspicion of these deals has clearly not faded, and in Latitude’s case there was particularly concerns about the possibility that there has been an under-investment in technology, given IT spending in the 2020 financial year was to double compared with 2018.

It wasn’t a fintech. Not really. Yes, there was technology there, and robust credit models that were built, tested and tweaked well before anyone got excited about algorithms that do the same thing.

But Latitude looks and feels more like an old-school consumer finance business than a low-cost online lender just getting started. The company’s new foray in the fintech buy now, pay later space, was promising but untested.

It was leveraged to the health of the consumer - and one that is already heavily indebted.

It wasn’t a growth stock. The 5.8 per cent yield on offer was clearly attractive in a low rate environment, but it appears to have put Latitude in the value basket for many investors - who then rightly thought hard about buying a business from KKR and chief executive Ahmed Fahour, who was to receive a bonus of $22 million in shares not for growing the business, but for listing it.

It was exposed to regulatory risk in a landscape still shifting after the royal commission. It is understood international investors were particularly jittery around this, and struggled to differentiate between the pain being experienced by the banks, and Latitude, which hasn’t seen anything like this.

It wasn’t a business with strong consumer brands. Latitude’s history was as the provider of white label products for other firms, particularly key retail partners such as Harvey Norman, JB Hi-Fi and The Good Guys. Fahour was trying to change this but developing the Latitude brand across his product range, and to some success. But the float was very early in this still incomplete process.

Advertisement

The timing of this float was and wasn’t right.

The Latitude camp argued that in the last year alone, the big banks have reduced consumer lending by about 30 per cent, with Latitude growing its market share in this sector 9 per cent to 13 per cent. That put it at it number three in this market, behind Commonwealth Bank and Westpac, but ahead of NAB and ANZ.

But the fragility of the Australian economy – perhaps best underlined by the Reserve Bank cutting official interest rates to a new record low of 0.75 per cent just six days after the Latitude released its prospectus – would have given many institutional fund managers pause. How much exposure do investors really want to heavily indebted consumers with rates at emergency levels?

Hindsight is a wonderful thing of course, and this columnist has to admit that he is surprised that the Latitude float has failed to get altitude.

With rates so low, and investors so desperate for returns, it just felt that 5.8 per cent yield would be attractive enough, particularly given it was backed by a stable business that was expected to deliver a cash profit of $287.6 million in the year to June 30 2020, up from $248.4 million in the 2018 financial year, before Fahour arrived.

When the prospectus was released in late September, I also said Fahour was the right sort of front man to take Latitude out of the shadows – as the back-end provider of finance for the likes of Harvey Norman and JB H-Fi – and build the consumer brand that could help differentiate the business. And clearly he was highly motivated to get the deal away.

But in the end, Fahour, KKR and brokers Goldman Sachs, Macquarie Capital and UBS just couldn’t get generate the buzz required to get the deal over the line.

Did Fahour’s $51 million pay package take some if the attention away from the Latitude growth story? Possibly.

Advertisement

But the biggest problem was the investors couldn’t get comfortable that Latitude had a strong enough competitive advantage.

Yes, the relationships with big retailers provided strong channels for customer acquisition, and Latitude’s base of 2.6 million customers was sizeable. But the rise and rise of buy now, pay later firms such as Afterpay in recent years has shown underscored that these retail partnerships did not represent barriers against competition.

At the same time, credit cards and personal loans are fairly commoditised products, and given Latitude was only at the start of the journey to becoming a consumer-facing brand, it could hardly claim and particularly advantages in this market – perhaps beyond an ability to lend where the banks weren’t.

It seems highly unlikely KKR and its fellow owners would attempt a third run at the ASX boards. So the bigger question becomes what will it actually take for private equity-backed floats to shrug off the distrust of the market? Right now that’s very hard to answer.
description: It wasn’t one thing that killed the float of Latitude Financial for a second time, but many.
